newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks roar to sixth straight record close.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks roar to sixth straight record close.

text.p: Mexican shares shed some of their earlier gains, but still left even the recent slew of impressive gains far behind to notch up their sixth record close in a row on Tuesday.
Dealers said foreign and domestic investors crowded a market basking in euphoria in the wake of smoother than expected mid-term elections on Sunday, amid a strong tailwind blowing from Wall Street.
Final closing prices showed the blue chip IPC share index had soared 79.90 points, or 1.69 percent, to a new record of 4,821.14.
"Basically, what we are seeing is that players who stayed on the sidelines last week are rushing in on the benefits of great elections," a desk trader said.

"Investors are overweighting Mexico in their portfolios, and there has been a slew of country recommendations favoring Mexico, cutting Chile and Brazil," he added. "Furthermore, forecasts have been upgraded for key indicators."

A Salomon Brothers report released on Tuesday said the brokerage was "shifting weight to Mexico from Chile," as short-term risk in Mexico had been reduced by "the perceived integrity of the July 6 elections."
Caspian Research meanwhile issued a report raising their year-end target for the IPC to 5,500 points from 4,700, based on "clean, transparent and peaceful" mid-term elections.
Mexico held elections on Sunday for the lower house of Congress, one quarter of the Senate, several state governors and for the first time in modern history, Mexico City mayor.

Analysts noted the elections were relatively free of fraud allegations, and the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party gracefully accepted preliminary returns showing it had suffered its worst setback since 1929.
Dealers said they had so many buy orders the bourse needed to impose trading halts and use a screen-trading back-up system to handle a record level of more than 8,200 deals settled.
"We were spinning around like firecrackers," one floor trader said.
Trading volume and turnover were very heavy at more than 199 million shares and $350 million, respectively.
Dealers said blue chips and ADRs led the rally.
"Most ADRs are flying and foreigners flooded the market," another floor trader said.
"Telmex has been pulling up the market since this morning, Bancomer is going crazy, and they're also fighting to buy Cemex," a desk trader said.
Telfonos de Mxico (Telmex), which has the heaviest weighting on the IPC, gained 15 centavos to 20.75 pesos, a peso record.
The telecom's ADRs advanced 7/8 to 52-3/4, their highest level since the December 1994 peso crisis. The Dow Jones meanwhile gained 103.81 to end at a record of 7,962.31.
Bancomer, one of Mexico's biggest financial firms, gained 28 centavos to 4.70 pesos.
Dealers said financial stocks in general gained on expectations forecast cuts in domestic interest rates would ease their past-due loans burdens.
Bancomer and Telmex together accounted for some 23 percent of all shares traded.
Cement maker Cemex meanwhile climbed 1.40 pesos to 37.90 pesos.
On the broad market, gainers far outstripped decliners, by 92 to 26, out of a total of 134 stocks that changed hands.
